Laboratory of Chemical Technology and Catalysis, Department of Inorganic and Organic Chemistry, Biochemistry and Catalysis, Faculty of Chemistry, University of Bucharest 4-12 Blvd. Regina Elisabeta Bucharest 030018 Romania Several M-MgFe-LDH precursors were prepared via co-precipitation and then calcined at 500 °C to yield the corresponding M-MgFeO mixed oxide catalysts, which were tested in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of benzyl alcohol. The prepared LDH contained Mg and Fe in a mol ratio of 3:1 and 10 at% M with respect to cations, where M = Ni, Co, Ag and Cu. The Cu-MgFeO mixed oxide gave the best results, therefore we proceeded with the preparation of a Cu(x)-MgFeO series, where x = 2.5–20 at% Cu. The prepared solids were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, temperature-programmed reduction with H2, temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. We studied the influence of the nature of the transition metal M on the activity and selectivity of the catalysts and, for the Cu-containing samples, the influence of Cu loading, reaction time and reaction temperature on their performance in the HDO reaction of benzyl alcohol. With 93.8% conversion and 93.8% selectivity towards toluene at 230 °C, 3 h reaction time and under a hydrogen pressure of 5 atm, the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst proved to have the best performance in the studied reaction. Therefore, its stability and reusability were checked. We also proposed a sequence of reactions for the entire HDO process, based on a reverse Mars-van Krevelen mechanism driven by oxygen vacancies formed on the catalyst surface. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Mixed oxide LDH Copper Hydrodeoxygenation Reverse Mars-van Krevelen mechanism Benzyl alcohol Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the last decades, given the need to tackle and prevent further worsening of global warming, the reduction of emissions of greenhouse gases has become the subject of many climate-related policies [1,2]. Therefore, the development of friendlier, sustainable non-fossil sources for the production of energy and fuels is one way of reducing our reliance on non-regenerable energy sources, while the compatibility with the current infrastructure is maintained [3,4]. In this regard, biomass is a cheap, naturally heavily abundant and accessible resource for generating energy and obtaining various valuable chemicals, being the only known renewable raw material that can be used for producing diesel-quality fuels [2,5]. It is a product of the processing of plants and other ligno-cellulosic materials, its main three components being lignin, hemicellulose and cellulose, but it can also be derived from waste or inedible sources [5,6]. The depolymerized lignin, or bio-oil, yielded through thermal treatment of lignocellulosic biomass and mainly comprised of mono-/oligomeric substituted phenols, can be employed as the starting material for the production of biofuels [4,7]. However, this fraction is usually rich in oxygen, with a 35–40 wt% content, whereas typical heavy hydrocarbon mixtures only contain about 1 wt% oxygen [8]. Such oxygen-rich fractions are inadequate for large-scale use as fuels because of their instability at low temperatures and against oxidizing agents, corroding action on the engines, high viscosity and immiscibility with hydrocarbons found in conventional diesel [8–10]. Subsequently, the bio-oil must be converted through a technically challenging deoxygenation step [4], which can be performed, among other methods, via catalytic refining processes such as cracking on zeolites, steam reforming or hydrodeoxygenation [11]. Hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) is an efficient method of removing oxygen from oxygenated compounds and converting them into high-energy, easily combustible hydrocarbons or valuable chemicals [4]. In this process, the bio-oil is thermally treated at temperatures of 200–400 ⁰C and hydrogen pressures of up to 200 atm, when the direct (at over 230 ⁰C) or indirect (at under 150 ⁰C) hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds and the subsequent removal of oxygen in the form of H2O molecules take place [7,12]. The selective hydrogenation of the oxygenated aromatic compounds is usually desired, especially when the conservation of certain functional groups is of particular interest in the production of chemicals derived from biomass [12,13]. Effective catalysts for such hydrotreating processes usually present two distinct features and are deemed to be bifunctional materials. They consist of an oxide of a transition metal that can readily modify its valence (for activating oxygen-containing functional groups), which can also be a Lewis/Brønsted acid, and a transition metal found in a reduced state (for activating the H2 molecules) [14,15]. Therefore, a suite of reactions catalyzed by both acid and metal functions takes place, these two components acting either independently or cooperatively in the HDO process [15]. Examples of such bifunctional materials include conventional hydrotreating catalysts, such as sulphided Co-Mo/Al2O3 and Ni-Mo/Al2O3 (which are efficient, but the need to add H2S or CS2 to keep them in sulphided form leads to product contamination and unwanted reduction of the catalyst activity) [8,15,16], supported noble metal catalysts, like Pt/HZM-5, Pd/HFAU or Pt/γ-Al2O3, or catalysts based on Fe, Co, Ni, Ru, Rh or Ir [7,16]. While such materials were proven to be useful in the HDO reaction, many other side reactions can occur, such as decarbonylation, hydrogenation or (hydro)cracking processes, which is why the selection of an appropriate catalyst is crucial for obtaining good selectivities towards the HDO reaction [11]. Several comprehensive reviews were published so far on the HDO process, catalysts and reaction mechanisms [17–24], also discussing the necessary steps in preparation for large scale use. Benzyl alcohol is a molecule often used to model reactions and processes pertaining to the valorization of lignocellulosic biomass, which naturally include HDO reactions. Excellent results have been obtained in homogenous transfer hydrogenation catalysis. The use of molybdate-type catalysts and isopropyl alcohol as a hydrogen source led to a yield of 93% in toluene [25], while the use of a Pd-based complex led to 99% conversion with 100% selectivity towards toluene at only 100 ⁰C and 20 atm of H2 [26]. Noble metal-based heterogeneous catalysts also exhibited satisfactory performances, as was the case for Pd nanoparticles supported on amphiphilic particles [27], Pt deposited on Al2O3, TiO2, CeO2, SiO2-Al2O3 supports modified with phosphonic acids [28] and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts functionalized with alkanethiolate self-assembled monolayers (SAMs) [29], these last two alterations drastically improving the selectivity towards toluene. Furthermore, Pd/Al2O3 covered with a combination of 1-adamantanethiol and 1-octadecanethiol SAMs in different proportions proved to be an exceptionally performant catalyst, with a reported 98% selectivity towards toluene at almost 100% conversion [30]. However, such materials also exhibit significant drawbacks, mainly the drastic drop in activity due to the formation of carbonaceous deposits on Pt or Pd surfaces [8] and their significant cost, which makes highly desirable the replacement of noble metals with other transition metals [12]. Consequently, the HDO of various oxygenated aromatics, including benzyl alcohol, was reported for a CuCr2O4∙CuO catalyst in decalin as a solvent, when conversion values as high as 100% and minimal coke deposition were observed [31]. In our previous work, a Cu-MgAlO mixed oxide catalyst derived from a layered double hydroxide (LDH) precursor led to a benzyl alcohol conversion of 87.5% with a selectivity towards toluene of 83.4% after 3 h reaction time (which increased to 97% and 96%, respectively, after 5 h) at 230 ⁰C and low H2 pressure of 5 atm [12]. These results are not surprising, as the Cu-based mixed oxides are known to prevent the hydrogenation of the aromatic ring, while exhibiting high activity in hydrogenolysis (e.g., of glycerol) [31–38] and catalytic transfer hydrogenation reactions [39]. The LDH precursors are a valuable choice due to the high dispersion and resistance to the sintering of the active metal [12]. This paper discusses the results of the HDO of benzyl alcohol process on M-MgFeO mixed oxide catalysts (M = Ni, Co, Ag, Cu) derived from LDH precursors via thermal decomposition. The metals M were chosen for their redox properties, while compared to our previous study concerning a Cu-MgAlO catalyst [12] aluminium was replaced with iron in order to modify the acid-base properties. The influence of the nature of metal M, as well as of the reaction temperature, time and Cu loading in the Cu(x)-MgFeO series upon the catalysts’ performance was analyzed in order to determine the optimal catalytic composition and process conditions. Afterwards, a sequence of reactions for the HDO process of benzyl alcohol was proposed. Finally, the catalyst stability after multiple HDO reactions on benzyl alcohol was assessed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation Ten M-MgFeO mixed oxides with a Mg-to-Fe molar ratio of 3 and 10 at% M (where M = Ni, Co, Ag) or 2.5–20 at% Cu (for M = Cu) with respect to cations were prepared via coprecipitation of the LDH precursors at a pH value of 10 ± 0.5 followed by their thermal decomposition. Mg(NO3)2∙6 H2O, Fe(NO3)3∙9 H2O, Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O, Ni(NO3)2∙6 H2O, Co(NO3)2∙6 H2O, (Sigma Aldrich) and AgNO3 (Merck) were used for the preparation of the M-MgFe-LDH precursors, without further purification. A 2 M solution of NaOH (Riedel-de Haën) was used as precipitating agent and added dropwise, under stirring, to a beaker containing 50 mL of distilled water, concomitantly with the dropwise addition of a solution of the necessary metal salts. The pH value of 10 was carefully and constantly monitored throughout the preparation process. The resulting brown suspension was transferred to a two-neck flat-bottom flask and left to age overnight at 80 ⁰C under reflux and vigorous stirring [40]. Then, the precipitate was separated via centrifugation, washed several times with distilled water until the pH value dropped below 7 and dried overnight at 80 ⁰C. The LDH precursors (denoted M-MgFe-LDH) were then finely ground and calcined at 500 ⁰C for 5 h in a static air atmosphere to yield the desired mixed oxide catalysts (denoted M-MgFeO). In the following sections of the paper, the copper-containing catalysts were labeled as Cu(x)-MgFeO, where x is the atomic percent of Cu which takes values between 2.5 and 20. For comparison, a pure CuO catalyst was prepared by precipitating Cu(NO3)2∙3 H2O with the same NaOH solution and following the exact same procedure as that described above. 2.2 Catalysts characterization The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of both the LDH precursors and the mixed oxides were recorded using a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα monochromatic radiation source (λ = 1.5406 Å) operating at 40 kV and 30 mA. The diffractograms were acquired in the 3–80⁰ 2-theta range for the LDH precursors and the 10–80⁰ 2-theta range for the mixed oxides, the set step width being 0.02⁰ and the scanning speed 2⁰/min. The results were interpreted using the PDXL programme of the Rigaku diffractometer and the ICDD PDF-2 database. The average crystallite sizes for each LDH precursor and its corresponding mixed oxide were calculated using the Debye-Scherrer equation. The textural analysis of the mixed oxide catalysts was performed through adsorption-desorption of N2 at − 196 ⁰C (77.15 K) using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. Prior to each measurement, the samples were degassed under vacuum at 300 ⁰C for 4 h. The specific surface areas of the mixed oxides were calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) equation and the total pore volume of each material was approximated by nitrogen adsorption at relative pressures of circa 0.99–1.00. The mean pore diameters were calculated using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, and the values on the desorption branches of the recorded isotherms were used to plot the pore size distribution curves for each analyzed solid. The elemental analyses were performed with a Zeiss EVO MA15 Scanning Electron Microscope (SEM) coupled with an Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDX) system, provided by Thermo Scientific, which uses a Silicone Drift Detector (SDD) with an energy resolution of 129 eV (Mn-Kα). The parameters used for analysis were as follows: a 20 kV accelerating voltage with a probe current between 923 pA and 1.2 nA at a working distance of 6–7 mm. All the samples were analyzed under the same conditions in high vacuum and for each one at least 3 points of measurement were taken. The end results are an average of these measurements and additionally, elemental mapping was performed in order to emphasize the uniform distribution of the elements of interest. Each oxide was fixed on the sample support using carbon tape. The reducibility of the mixed oxides was investigated via temperature-programmed reduction in hydrogen (H2-TPR), while a temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) analysis provided information regarding their basicity. These experiments were performed on a Quantachrome ChemBET-3000 analyzer equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). Prior to the H2-TPR analysis the samples were thermally treated for 30 min in an Ar flow at 450 ⁰C, cooled down to room temperature and then exposed to a flow of reducing mixture consisting of 5% H2 in Ar. The mixture flow rate was maintained constant at 70 mL/min and the heating rate was set to 10 ⁰C/min until the temperature of 900 ⁰C was reached. The samples were then brought back to room temperature. For the CO2-TPD experiment each sample was heated to 100 ⁰C in a He flow with a 10 ⁰C/min heating rate. Then, the temperature was increased to 300 ⁰C with the same heating rate as the samples were exposed to a CO2 flow; the samples were held for 1 h at this temperature to ensure adsorption of CO2 molecules on the surface and then cooled down to room temperature in the same CO2 flow. In order to remove physisorbed molecules on the oxidic surface, the mixed oxides were placed under a He flow for 1 h. Finally, the temperature was gradually increased to 550 ⁰C (10 ⁰C/min heating rate) under the same He flow, the signal generated by the gradual desorption of CO2 molecules from the surface being registered. The samples were brought back to room temperature following the completion of the analysis. 2.3 Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation tests All catalytic tests were conducted in a stainless-steel autoclave (HEL Limited) with an internal volume of 16 mL, which was heated and magnetically stirred in a heating jacket on a hotplate. A thermocouple was used to closely monitor the temperature. For every catalytic test, 1 mL of benzyl alcohol (Merck, p.a.) was added alongside 50 mg of mixed oxide and 5 atm of H2 (Linde, 99.998%), while the reaction conditions were set to 230 ⁰C and 3 h reaction time. With the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst, reactions were ran at temperatures held between 150 and 230 ⁰C and reaction time values in the range of 15 min to 5 h. After the autoclave temperature dropped to room temperature, the liquid and gaseous reaction products were collected and analyzed. The gaseous mixture was analyzed with a Trace GC chromatograph (CE Instruments) equipped with a Carboxen column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) using He (99.99%) as carrier gas. The gaseous products always consisted of unreacted H2 and traces of CO and CO2, irrespective of the type of catalyst that was used. Water produced during the HDO reaction did not form a separate phase, but converted the mixed oxide catalyst into a LDH phase that also embedded the organic phase. The liquid reaction products were extracted from this catalytic product suspension with isopropyl alcohol (Lachner, 99.7%), then centrifuged in order to separate the products extracted in alcohol from the solid catalyst particles suspended within. The liquid products were analyzed by a Trace GC chromatograph (ThermoFinnigan) equipped with a DB-5 column and a flame ionization detector (FID) using N2 (> 99.5%) as a carrier gas. In almost all cases, the detected liquid reaction products were toluene, benzaldehyde, benzene and benzyl benzoate, the latter two being formed in negligible amounts in some of the catalytic tests. The conversion of benzyl alcohol and the selectivities towards each of the reaction products were calculated as previously described [12]. In order to study the sequence of reactions involved in the hydrodeoxygenation of benzyl alcohol, benzaldehyde, benzyl benzoate and toluene were also employed as substrates for catalytic tests ran using the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst. The working conditions were the optimum reaction conditions identified for benzyl alcohol conversion: 50 mg of catalyst, 1 mL of substrate and 5 atm of H2 at 230 ⁰C for 3 h. These have also been the reaction conditions for the recyclability tests. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalysts characterization The powder XRD patterns of the LDH precursors are shown in Fig. 1. The base pyroauritic material, MgFe-LDH, exhibits typical diffraction lines for such layered structures (PDF 00–900–9439), the intense and narrow lines at 2-theta values of 11 and 23⁰ being ascribed to the (003) and (006) reflections. In the 30–60⁰ 2-theta range, asymmetrical peaks corresponding to (012), (015), (018), (110) and (113) reflections, typical for such structures derived from hydrotalcite, are observed [12,41]. These diffraction lines are specific to a hexagonal crystalline lattice exhibiting the R3m symmetry. The XRD patterns of the Cu(x)-MgFe-LDH precursors are similar, except for the sample containing 20 at% Cu, i.e. Cu(20)-MgFe-LDH. This particular material displays two additional intense diffraction lines in the 35–40⁰ 2-theta region ascribed to a segregated tenorite phase (CuO, PDF 04–007–0518), as already reported for other Cu-containing MgAl- and MgFe-LDH systems with high Cu loading [12,42]. For the M-MgFe-LDH samples, the unit cell parameters a and c were calculated from the positions of the (110) and (003) reflections using the following relationships: a = 2 × d 110 and c = 3 × d 003 ( Table 1). For all M-MgFe-LDH samples, the value of the cell parameter a is very close to that of the MgFe-LDH solid (0.312 ± 0.005 nm), indicating that the variation of the average intermetallic distances within the brucitic framework is minimal upon Mg2+ substitution. It is noteworthy that the variation of the cell parameter a as a function of M can hardly be discussed because the M2+/M3+ molar ratio is different among the M-MgFe-LDH samples. However, the similarity of this parameter for the Ag-MgFe-LDH and MgFe-LDH samples, in spite of the high ionic radius of Ag+ cation, suggests that it is not located into the brucite-like layer. This is confirmed by the segregation of Ag particles observed after calcination ( Fig. 2a). On the other hand, a variation of the cell parameter a irrespective of the Cu content can be noticed within the Cu(x)-MgFe-LDH series (Table 1), when the Cu2+ ions, due to their pronounced Jahn-Teller effect, tend to adopt distorted geometries or even leave the brucitic matrix (the latter situation is encountered in the case of the Cu(20)-MgFe-LDH precursor, when a segregated CuO phase is formed because of the excessive Cu loading) [43]. Such a phenomenon leads to the alteration of these intermetallic distances, being responsible, at least partly, for the observed modification of the cell parameter a in this series. The calculated cell parameter c values are specific for layered double hydroxides containing nitrate ions in between the layers, but they can also depend on factors other than the nature of the anion, such as the average charge of the layers or the amount of interstitial water molecules [12,43–45]. The Debye-Scherrer equation was employed to approximate the average crystallite size of the M-MgFe-LDH precursors. The calculations were done using the (003) reflection, the obtained values being displayed in Table 1. The average crystallite sizes, calculated along the c crystallographic axis (the direction of layer stacking, perpendicular to the brucitic layers), are close together, ranging from 4.6 nm (Ni-MgFe-LDH) to 7.7 nm (Ag-MgFe-LDH). The Cu-containing samples with 5, 15 and 20 at% Cu have virtually equal average crystallite sizes (7.0–7.1 nm), being slightly lower for the Cu(10)-MgFe-LDH making an exception (6.1 nm) and, hence, any correlation between the Cu loading and the crystallite size can be rouled out. Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of the mixed oxides obtained by thermal decomposition of the LDH precursors. All samples exhibit two intense diffraction lines at 43 and 62⁰ 2-theta, ascribed to the (200) and (220) reflections, respectively, specific to a periclase-type Mg(Fe)O phase (PDF 00–900–5516). For the Ag- and Cu(20)-MgFeO mixed oxides, diffraction lines specific to different side phases were also noticed. Thus, the Ag-MgFeO sample contains metallic Ag particles separated from the periclase-like framework with an average particle size of 26.8 nm. This is due to the fact that Ag+ has a significantly greater ionic radius compared to Fe3+ or Mg2+ (129 pm versus 78.5 and 86 pm, respectively), which makes the total integration of these ions in the Mg(Fe)O structure less likely. A similar segregation event was reported for a Ag-MgAlO mixed oxide with 5 at% Ag [46]. The Cu(20)-MgFeO sample expectedly presents a tenorite segregated phase, proven by the two intense diffraction lines located in the 30–40⁰ 2-theta range and associated with the (−111) and (111) reflections, as well as the less intense ones located at 2-theta values higher than 50⁰. Apart from these two particular cases, the Mn+ species are probably well dispersed throughout the periclase-type matrix, assumption supported by the SEM mapping images (see Fig. S1 in the Supplementary information), and the fact that the values of the cell parameter a (calculated using the (200) reflections) are close together (0.421 ± 0.002 nm, see Table 2). Finally, it is noteworthy that the presence of tiny amounts of a maghemite phase (Fe2O3, PDF 00–900–6316), whose diffraction lines are close to those specific to the Mg(Fe)O periclase-like phase, cannot be completely ruled out. Moreover, due to their similar ionic radii, the isomorphic substitution of some Mg2+ cations with Cu2+ is possible thus resulting in more complex compositions. The average crystallite sizes for the mixed oxides were also estimated using the Debye-Scherrer equation applied to the (200) and (220) reflections (Table 2). Ni-MgFeO has the smallest crystallites (4.7 nm), while MgFeO sits at the opposite end of the scale, with an average crystallite size of 7.8 nm. Within the Cu(x)-MgFeO series, the oxides display crystallite size values decreasing with increasing Cu content from 7.5 nm for x = 2.5–6.3 ± 0.1 nm for x = 5, 7.5, 10 and 15 and, then, to 5.7 nm for x = 20. The chemical composition of the M-MgFeO and Cu(x)-MgFeO mixed oxides has been estimated via EDX analysis, the transition metal M atomic content and the Mg/Fe ratio being reported in Table 2. It can be observed that for all M- and Cu(x)-MgFeO samples, the transition metal M content is close to the theoretical value. The Mg/Fe atomic ratio is equal to or lower than that in the synthesis solution, likely due to the variation of pH during the synthesis of the LDH precursor. Indeed, it has been shown that the incorporation of Mg in the LDH framework strongly depends on the coprecipitation pH in the 9.5–11 range [47]. However, it is worth noting that the exact composition of the layers for the trimetallic LDH materials can hardly be established, especially for those containing Cu, which is difficult to introduce due to its pronounced Jahn-Teller effect. Fig. 3 displays the XRD patterns recorded for the spent Cu(10)-MgFeO, retrieved after one reaction and immediately dried in a He flow at 200 ⁰C for 4 h (to evaporate the adsorbed reaction products without reoxidizing the solid), and for the twice-used, recalcined in air Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst. For comparison purposes, the diffractogram of the freshly calcined catalyst has been included. The spent and dried in He sample presents diffraction lines specific to a Cu2O phase (PDF 01–071–3645) at 37, 42, 62 and 74⁰ 2-theta corresponding to (111), (200), (220) and (311) reflections. These are most likely superimposed over the diffraction lines at 43, 62 and 75⁰ 2-theta corresponding to the periclase-like Mg(Fe)O phase. Additional reflections given by a reconstructed LDH phase are observed at lower 2-theta values. This latter phase most likely contains in the interlayer space compensating anions found in the reaction medium, such as benzoates and benzylates. This reconstruction process is plausible when the reaction takes place in solvo- or hydrothermal conditions [12]. The latter assumption was verified by acquiring the XRD pattern for the twice-used and recalcined catalyst, which no longer displays the diffraction lines located at 10–25⁰ 2-theta values and attributed to the pyroaurite phase. Only the reflections ascribed to the periclase and tenorite phases were observed in this case. Notably, although most of the diffraction lines for copper oxide phases are superimposed to some degree, the spent and dried in He sample contained a significant amount of Cu+ species, judging by the reddish tint of the solid, specific to Cu2O. In conclusion, the structure of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst is not entirely conserved after usage and recalcination, detectable CuO amounts being separated from the periclase-type matrix. As the presence in the freshly calcined sample of small, well dispersed CuO particles, although not detected by XRD, cannot be ruled out, their increase in size can also take place during the catalytic process and recalcination. In time, these phenomena can influence the catalyst stability, as discussed later on. All analyzed oxides exhibit type IV adsorption-desorption isotherms with a combination of H2a and H2b hysteresis loops ( Fig. 4), characteristic for mesoporous solids with complex pore networks [48]. The M-MgFeO materials have specific surface areas ranging from 107 m2/g (MgFeO) to 186 m2/g (Ni-MgFeO), varying in accordance with their average crystallite sizes (Table 2). In the case of the Cu(x)-MgFeO catalysts, no clear relationship between the specific surface areas and the Cu content could be noticed. However, Cu(20)-MgFeO has the smallest surface area in this series, of roughly 97 m2/g. This could be attributed to the formation of a bulk CuO side-phase, which diminishes the specific surface area of the actual catalyst. A similar anomaly can be noticed in the case of Ag-MgFeO system, which exhibits a considerably smaller surface area compared to Co-MgFeO (111 vs. 143 m2/g), despite both having similar average crystallite sizes (5.5 vs. 5.6 nm) of the periclase-like phase. This is due to the segregation of the metallic Ag phase in Ag-MgFeO, leading to a decrease in the measured specific surface area. The pore size distribution plots are shown in Fig. S2. The M-MgFeO solids show narrow, unimodal distributions with narrow mesopores (less than 20 nm in diameter), while the Cu(x)-MgFeO materials have significantly less regular distributions, most of them exhibiting „shoulders” and thus being considerably larger. However, among the latter series, the catalyst containing 10 at% Cu displays a rather narrow pore size distribution with narrow mesopores (under 15–20 nm in diameter) in a unimodal pore network, as opposed to the other Cu-containing oxides. The pore volumes range from 0.29 cm3/g for Cu(20)-MgFeO to 0.65 cm3/g for Cu(5)-MgFeO, with the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst having the same total pore volume as the unmodified MgFeO solid (0.36 cm3/g). The prepared catalysts have also been characterized by means of H2-TPR in order to study their reductibility and correlate the observed redox properties with their catalytic activity. The reduction curves are displayed in Fig. 5, while both the measured and the maximum theoretical hydrogen consumptions, as well as the temperatures corresponding to the reduction peaks (Tmax) are shown in Table 3. Each peak of the obtained H2-TPR profiles has been decomposed in a number of Gaussian components using the Origin 6.1 program, satisfactory agreement factors being obtained in all cases (at least 0.995 in the M-MgFeO series and at least 0.998 in the Cu(x)-MgFeO series). Due to the different nature of the cations and the phases present in the analyzed solids, they are expected to exhibit different reduction patterns and Tmax values. The TPR profile of the MgFeO sample (Fig. 5a) could be decomposed into three peaks, at around 445 °C, 500 °C and 595 °C, respectively. The first two can be attributed to Fe3+ reduction from the periclase-like Mg(Fe)O mixed oxide [41,49,50]. The last one might belong to the same reduction in the Fe2O3 phase that could not be ruled out based on XRD diffractograms. While the reduction of Mg2+ sites does not take place, their presence might have a retarding effect upon the reduction of the Fe sites compared to a pure Fe2O3 phase [44,50]. A high temperature, low-intensity broad peak (800–900 °C) was assigned to spinel phases that can form at high temperatures. The Ni- and Co-MgFeO samples (Fig. 5a) were reduced with similar patterns, but at slightly lower temperatures than MgFeO, and their profiles could also be decomposed into several peaks that can be assigned to transition-metal oxide particles interacting more or less strongly with the Mg(Fe)O matrix. For the Ni-MgFeO sample a broad and intense high-temperature peak was observed, that can be explained by the dissociation of H2 on the already reduced Ni, followed by spillover of the atomic hydrogen that, in turn, facilitates reduction of iron species [51]. A particularly interesting case is the reduction of the Ag-MgFeO sample, the corresponding plot displaying reduction maxima for Ag+ and Fe3+ strongly shifted to lower temperatures. While the facile reduction of a fraction of the well dispersed Ag2O particles throughout the periclase matrix has already been reported [46], it is worth noting that the Fe3+ reduction signal is rather broad. The stark decrease in temperature is mainly attributed to the presence of the Ag species in the sample, which easily dissociate the adsorbed H2 molecules, leading to a spillover effect, which in turn ensures the facile reduction of the mixed oxide [13]. For the Cu(x)-MgFeO oxides, the reduction peaks visible at around 240–370 ⁰C are specific to the reduction of more or less dispersed Cu species in the periclase-like Mg(Fe)O matrix under the form of CuO particles having different degrees of interaction with the support. In addition, the existence of small quantities of amorphous CuO deposited on the oxide surface, but undetected during the XRD analysis except for the sample with 20 at% Cu, could contribute to the total area of these peaks. As the Cu loading increased, this low temperature peak becomes broader, starts at slightly lower temperatures and can be decomposed in up to four components, assigned to species with different degrees of dispersion [42]. The reduction peak with a maximum located in the range 350–410 °C is assigned to the reduction of Fe3+ ions, while at high temperatures the low-intensity peaks were attributed to spinel phases that likely form in the heating step during the analysis. Except for Cu(5)-MgFeO, these solids had higher hydrogen consumption and reduction degrees than the rest of the M-MgFeO catalysts, that were increasing with the copper loading. The basicity of the mixed oxides was evaluated via CO2-TPD, the plotted normalized curves being shown in Fig. 6, while the data regarding the types and proportions of basic sites can be found in Table 4. Usually, following the calcination of LDH materials, the generated mixed oxides contain different types of basic sites, such as weak basic Brønsted sites (hydroxyl groups left on the oxidic surface after calcination), medium strength Lewis basic sites (acid-base pairs like Mg2+-O2- or Fe3+-O2-, as well as Mn+-O2- generated upon insertion of transition metals M) and strong basic Lewis sites (incompletely coordinated O2- ions) [52]. In our case, in the 100–250 ⁰C temperature range, maxima corresponding to the desorption of CO2 molecules from weak and medium strength basic sites can be seen (most evident for the MgFeO sample), while in the 300–450 ⁰C interval, desorption from strong basic sites occurs. The MgFeO mixed oxide displays a ratio of approx. 1:2 for the weak to strong basic sites but, once Mn+ species are added to the samples, the number of strong Lewis basic sites sharply increases. This phenomenon is most likely attributed to the fact that the introduction of such cations leads to the formation of new Lewis sites, such as Mn+-O2- pairs. For the M-MgFeO samples, not only did the number of strong basic sites increase, but the number of weak basic sites also decreased upon M addition. In the Cu(x)-MgFeO series, the number of both types of basic sites increases, as well as the percentage of strong basic sites compared to the MgFeO sample free of Cu, the maximum being recorded for the Cu(15)-MgFeO mixed oxide. Nevertheless, the material containing 20 at% Cu does not fit this trend and is less basic than its predecessor in the series, supposedly because of deactivation of some sites by the bulk CuO phase formed on the oxide surface. For this series an increase in the high temperature maximum was observed as the copper loading increased from 5 to 10 at% (from ∼353 to ∼373 °C), indicating an enhanced basic strength, but then remained the same for the samples with higher Cu loading. Out of all the studied samples, the Cu(15)-MgFeO and Co-MgFeO seem to be the most basic materials in terms of the total number of basic sites (Table 4). 3.2 Catalytic tests The values of the conversions and selectivities registered for the HDO reactions of benzyl alcohol performed on the M-MgFeO and Cu(x)-MgFeO catalysts are tabulated in Table 5. The main reaction products observed were in all cases toluene and benzaldehyde, with small amounts of benzyl benzoate and traces of benzene. The data in Table 5 show that the nature of the transition metal M has a strong influence on the catalytic performance, not only in terms of conversion of benzyl alcohol, but also in terms of product distribution. The addition of a transition metal M to the MgFeO mixed oxide increases the activity of the catalyst, from 7.7% alcohol conversion using MgFeO, to 61.8% and 93.8% for the Ag- and Cu-MgFeO systems, respectively. While the values of the selectivity towards toluene widely vary from system to system, the remarkable selectivity of ca. 94% achieved by the Cu-containing catalyst must be evidenced. It should be remarked that, in all reactions, benzene was formed in negligible amounts (under 0.2% selectivity). Considering that even in the absence of a catalyst no significant quantity of this reaction product was detected, it can be assumed that the process conditions themselves, and not the nature of the catalyst, favour the HDO rather than the decarbonylation of benzaldehyde intermediate. In this case, the hypothesis of benzene formation via a dealkylation reaction of toluene can be excluded, as this process would generate methane as a by-product, which was not detected in the gaseous mixture. Such a reaction path is facilitated by Lewis acid catalysts [53–55]. It is well-known that the decarbonylation reaction competes with HDO, the latter being more desirable because it maximizes the carbon content of the products [28]. Obviously, the chosen process conditions, especially the use of hydrogen gas (decarbonylation can occur in the absence of hydrogen, while HDO requires hydrogen atmosphere [2]), decisively contributed towards the diminution of the benzene yield. A particularly interesting situation arose in the case of the Ag-MgFeO catalyst, which favours to a greater extent the formation of benzyl benzoate. Although benzoic acid was not observed among the reaction products in this case, we assume that it could be easily formed through the oxidation of benzaldehyde and then react with benzyl alcohol, forming benzyl benzoate. It should be noted that Ag is often a component of various catalysts employed for gas-/liquid-phase oxidation of aromatic and aliphatic alcohols, being especially effective for facilitating O2- species spillover on the surface of the solid [56]. In the case of the Ag-MgFeO catalyst, the Ag+-O2- surface species likely enable the oxidation of benzaldehyde to benzoic acid, as suggested by the easiness of reduction of the solid evidenced in the H2-TPR experiments, which could be associated with the availability of the oxygen species to attack the electrophile center formed on the carbonyl carbon atom. However, the facile formation of Ag0-□-Fe2+ oxygen vacancies on the surface of the solid can also entail the activation of benzyl alcohol and benzaldehyde molecules for the HDO reaction [13], hypothesis confirmed by the 61% selectivity towards toluene. It is obvious, from the data in Table 5, that the presence of the Cu sites in the catalyst is essential not only for achieving good conversions in the HDO process, but also for directing it towards the formation of toluene via benzyl alcohol deoxygenation. Consequently, the influence of the Cu loading on the catalytic performance in the reaction of interest has been studied by performing tests using as catalysts a Cu(x)-MgFeO series, CuO and Cu2+ ions (from Cu(NO3)2·3 H2O dissolved directly in benzyl alcohol), for reference, while the reaction conditions were kept unchanged. A steep increase in conversion with Cu loading is observed between 2.5 and 10 at% Cu, reaching a maximum of ca. 94%. Then, it decreases to ca. 82% for Cu(15)-MgFeO, and finally it slightly increases to ca. 86% for the Cu(20)-MgFeO catalyst. This last increase in conversion likely occurs because of the high activity of the segregated CuO particles deposited on the catalyst surface, as highlighted by XRD. On the other hand, this tenorite phase does not lead to a better selectivity towards toluene, as it is not highly selective by itself (Table 5). Indeed, the selectivity passes through a maximum of ca. 94% for the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst, then it decreases with the increase of the Cu content. Notably, the evolution of the selectivity towards benzaldehyde closely mirrors that for toluene as a function of the Cu content, which suggests that besides direct hydrogenolysis of benzyl alcohol into toluene, a pathway implying benzaldehyde as a reaction intermediate is also involved, the overall transformation depending on the dispersion of the Cu active sites throughout the mixed oxide. No significant amounts of benzene were formed, while the selectivities towards benzyl benzoate were generally low. A HDO reaction test with soluble Cu2+ ions has been performed, the amount of Cu2+ ions used in this reaction being equivalent to the theoretical quantity of Cu found within the Cu(10)-MgFeO mixed oxide. The 54% conversion observed in this instance proves that, if leaching of Cu2+ ions occurs during the heterogeneous process, these could further catalyze the HDO reaction, leading to a homogenous-heterogeneous catalytic process. However, the selectivity towards toluene drastically drops compared to the heterogeneous reaction over the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst. These results suggest that the presence of an oxidic lattice capable of generating oxygen vacancies and that of Fe3+ sites needed to activate the oxygen-containing moieties are crucial for both selectivity and activity. No direct correlation could be established between the structural properties and the performance of the catalysts in the HDO reaction. However, the Cu loading and the dispersion of these active sites have a great impact on the observed conversion and selectivity values. These two characteristics are optimal in the case of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst, for which the Lewis acid-base pairs and the formed oxygen vacancies are in sufficient amounts and easily accessible for the reaction to take place efficiently. It is worth noting that this catalytic system is more active than the Cu-MgAlO catalyst previously tested [12], as it requires only 10 at% Cu compared to 15 at%, and the activity results are better in the same reaction conditions. Optimal dispersion of acid-base pair Mn+-O2- Lewis sites was shown to play a crucial role in the reversible transformation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde [57]. Indeed, the benzyl alcohol molecule is adsorbed dissociatively on a basic site, when a hydroxyl group and a benzylate-type Bn-O-M intermediate are formed (where Bn is a C6H5-CH2- moiety). Then, a hydride ion from the benzylic position is extracted by a nearby metal ion (Lewis site) resulting in the formation of the carbonyl group [57–59]. The high reducibility of the copper species facilitates the elimination of this hydride ion, explaining the good catalytic results for this sample, and both the proton and hydride can react in the conversion of benzaldehyde to toluene [57]. Since the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst performed the best in the HDO reaction of benzyl alcohol in the studied series, we proceeded to optimize the process conditions. First, the reaction time was varied in the range of 15 min to 5 h, conversion and selectivity curves being plotted in Figs. 7 a and 7 b, respectively. The conversion of benzyl alcohol increased up to ca. 94% during the first 3 h of reaction, then it slightly increased up to 97% during the next 2 h (Fig. 7 a), which is a typical conversion vs. reaction time variation for batch-type reactors. The selectivity towards toluene reached a maximum of ca. 94% after 3 h, followed by a slight decrease to ca. 91% during the next 2 h. It is noteworthy that the curves of the variation of the selectivities towards toluene and benzaldehyde, respectively, mirror each other once again, suggesting that benzaldehyde gradually transforms into toluene with increasing reaction time, thus playing the role of an intermediate in the transformation of benzyl alcohol into toluene. This is in close agreement with conclusion drawn by Rizescu et al. for the same reaction on a Cu-MgAlO catalyst [12], or by Gonzalez et al. for the HDO of benzaldehyde and benzyl alcohol on Pt or Pd/Al2O3 catalysts [8]. The selectivity towards benzyl benzoate remained roughly constant in time, suggesting that its formation/hydrolysis is not time-dependent. It can be concluded that 3 h is the optimal time for the HDO reaction to take place over the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst. The influence of the reaction temperature on the performance of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst was investigated in the 150–230 ⁰C temperature range. The conversion and selectivity versus temperature plots are illustrated in Figs. 8 a and 8b, respectively. An exponential increase of the conversion with the reaction temperature can be observed, which reaches ca. 94% at 230 °C (Fig. 8a). Toluene is the main reaction product in all cases, the selectivity towards this product passing through a maximum of 99.3% at 175 °C, then it only slightly decreased at higher temperatures. Only trace amounts of benzene were formed in the working temperature range, suggesting that toluene hydrodealkylation has very limited importance. This is also supported by the lack of methane in the gaseous products of the reaction. Notably, a significant amount of benzyl benzoate was noticed for the reaction at 150 °C, which might imply that its formation/consumption is temperature-dependent, the esterification-hydrolysis equilibrium being shifted in the hydrolysis direction at high temperatures. It can be concluded that conducting the HDO process at 230 ⁰C would be optimal for maximizing the toluene yield. In order to gain more information about the reactions taking place during the HDO process, three other substrates, i.e. benzaldehyde, benzyl benzoate and toluene, were subjected to the reaction conditions deemed optimal in the presence of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst. The results are tabulated in Table 6, which also includes the data obtained using benzyl alcohol for reference. It can be observed that toluene is practically inert in these conditions, the 0.01% conversion being attributed to the potential dealkylation reaction it undergoes on Lewis acid sites to yield benzene. However, toluene contribution to benzene formation is negligible and is in close agreement with the previous statement, confirming that, in reactions with benzyl alcohol, benzene most likely results via benzaldehyde decarbonylation [8]. Given the inertness of the toluene and the absence of compounds like cyclohexane or methylcyclohexane in the reaction products, benzene was also considered to be inert and, hence, was not tested in these conditions. Judging by its 23.6% conversion value, benzaldehyde exhibited moderate to low reactivity in these conditions. Nevertheless, the selectivities towards benzyl benzoate, toluene and benzyl alcohol suggest that benzaldehyde plays the role of an intermediate in the HDO of benzyl alcohol and transforms, to various degrees, in each of these products. The formation of benzyl alcohol serves as proof of the reversibility of the benzyl alcohol-benzaldehyde transformation, as discussed previously in this section and also observed in the literature [60,61]. Notably, in the reactions using either benzaldehyde or benzyl benzoate as substrate, significant quantities of benzoic acid have been detected during the chromatographic analysis. This proves that benzaldehyde can be oxidized to benzoic acid, which is then condensed with benzyl alcohol, yielding benzyl benzoate. Moreover, benzaldehyde was converted in a significant proportion to toluene, either through hydrogenation to benzyl alcohol, followed by the hydrogenolysis of the Csp3-O bond, or by direct hydrogenolysis of the carbonyl bond on the oxygen vacancies formed on the oxide surface. The selectivity towards benzene did not exceed 0.1% (except in the reaction with toluene, where conversion was extremely low), which once again suggests that this compound results via benzaldehyde decarbonylation. In regard to a similar process, Almithn et al. reported that Cu sites strongly favor a C-O bond hydrogenolysis reaction to a decarbonylation one (which implies C-C bond hydrogenolysis) [62], proving that it is more likely for toluene to form instead of benzene, as observed experimentally. Thus, benzaldehyde can be considered the main intermediate in this HDO process, all observed reaction products being formed either directly or indirectly from this molecule. The reaction done using benzyl benzoate led, with a good conversion of 36.5%, to selectivities towards toluene and bezaldehyde of 54.8% and ca. 9.7%, respectively. The benzyl benzoate molecules suffered, to some degree, a hydrolysis reaction, the lack of a significant number of strong acid sites probably limiting the complete shift of the equilibrium towards the formation of benzoic acid and benzyl alcohol molecules. 3.3 The sequence of reactions for the hydrodeoxygenation process The main and secondary reactions involved in the catalytic hydrodeoxygenation of benzyl alcohol are illustrated in Fig. 9: As shown in Section 3.2, benzaldehyde is the main reaction intermediate involved in the transformation of benzyl alcohol. Starting from benzaldehyde, the formation of the desired product, toluene, can take place in two different ways: i) directly through the hydrogenolysis of the carbonyl bond in benzaldehyde or ii) by means of a hydrogenation (of benzaldehyde) – hydrogenolysis (of benzyl alcohol) sequence [60]. Thus, on the Cu-MgFeO catalysts, toluene is formed through mechanisms that involve direct hydrogenolysis reactions, a hypothesis strongly supported by the H2-TPR analysis (Fig. 5) illustrating that the Cu2+ and Fe3+ sites readily reduce to Cu+ and Fe2+, respectively. Furthermore, the XRD pattern of the unoxidized spent Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst (Fig. 3) clearly shows reflections ascribed to a Cu2O phase, also proving that the material actually undergoes a reduction step. Such hydrogenolysis reactions are facilitated by the oxygen vacancies formed on the surface of the catalyst and take place through a reverse Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, typical for such easily reducible oxidic materials [63]. The hydrogen molecules present in the reaction medium act as a reducing agent upon the catalyst surface (following the dissociative adsorption on the metallic sites, a phenomenon that can even take place on Mn+-O2- Lewis acid-base pairs [64]), producing water molecules and highly reactive surface structural defects, namely the oxygen vacancies. It is a well-known fact that the Cu2+-O-Fe3+ ion pairs existing on the catalyst surface can readily modify their valence and generate highly reactive Cu+-□-Fe2+ oxygen vacancies. Well-dispersed CuO species in the periclase-like matrix can also show surface easily reducible Cu2+-O-Cu2+ groups that lead to the formation of Cu+-□-Cu+ vacancies, highly reactive themselves in the hydrodeoxygenation process [42]. Xiao et al. have already proven with the help of DFT calculations that the hydrogenolysis of C-O bonds on a surface incapable of generating oxygen vacancies is highly costly, in terms of the spent energy on breaking those bonds; on the other hand, the formation of such defects enables the catalyst to become a strong reductant by extracting the oxygen atoms from oxygenated molecules to regenerate its oxidic lattice, thus facilitating the hydrogenolysis [63]. In addition, Resende et al. suggested that a suprafacial Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism is also possible for such a transformation, both the molecular hydrogen and the oxygenated molecule being adsorbed on the surface, reacting and then the reaction products desorbing from the surface [65]. It is also worth noting that the presence of the aromatic ring in the immediate vicinity of the -CH2OH group is essential for stabilizing the intermediate formed after the scission of the Csp3-O bond through conjugation, therefore reducing the energy barrier associated with the hydrogenolysis process [64]. Hence, it can be assumed that the oxygen vacancies formed in the Cu-MgFeO mixed oxide play a role of utmost importance in this transformation of benzyl alcohol and that toluene is formed preponderently through a hydrogenation-hydrogenolysis mechanism. Moreover, a computational study conducted by Almithn et al. has demonstrated that the hydrogenolysis of Csp3-O bonds is energetically favoured on Group 11 transition metals (Cu, Ag, Au), a dehydrogenation step being unnecessary from an energy expense point of view. In fact, in this group, the surfaces containing Cu atoms exhibit the highest activity towards the hydrogenolysis of such C-O bonds [62]. Since the XRD pattern of the spent Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst does not show diffraction lines characteristic to metallic Cu (Fig. 3), we consider that only the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+ takes place during the HDO process in the conditions used. Benzene, as shown before, is a product of benzaldehyde decarbonylation and not one of toluene dealkylation. In addition, considering that in the mixture of reaction products no methanol was detected, it is safe to assume that there is a very slight chance of a direct Csp3-Car bond breaking reaction occurring, which would have also led to the formation of benzene molecules. Benzaldehyde can also be transformed into benzoic acid (and benzyl alcohol) through a Cannizzaro reaction, catalyzed by the basic sites [66]. Benzyl benzoate can be obtained either through the reaction between benzyl alcohol and the benzoic acid previously formed, or by a Tishchenko reaction between two benzaldehyde molecules, catalyzed by the metallic benzylates formed on the surface [12]. Dibenzylether is another, albeit secondary reaction product, which can form through the condensation of two molecules of benzyl alcohol, as reported elsewhere [67]. However, this compound was not detected during our catalytic tests, in line with the weak acidic properties of our catalysts – such condensation processes usually require Brønsted acid sites to take place in an efficient manner. The existence of a hemiacetalic intermediate resulting from the condensation of benzaldehyde with benzyl alcohol was also reported in other studies, but not detected in our products; nevertheless, this compound is unstable and quickly oxidizes to benzyl benzoate [67,68]. A comparison with the results reported in the literature for the HDO of benzyl alcohol (Table S1 ) shows that the alcohol conversion and selectivity to toluene obtained in this work are among the best so far, but in milder conditions (e.g., lower H2 pressure). The most relevant comparison concerns the reaction on CuxMgAlO catalysts [12], where the best results were obtained for x = 15 (15 at% Cu) in the same conditions as in this study. For Cu10MgAlO, slightly lower alcohol conversion and toluene selectivity values were obtained compared to its Cu(10)MgFeO counterpart. As discussed above, the activity of the Cu(x)-MgFeO systems is facilitated by the formation of oxygen vacancies. Thus, as the Al3+ species are not reducible, the formation of oxygen vacancies in the CuxMgAlO series is enabled only through the reduction of the Cu2+-O2--Cu2+ groups, while for the Cu(x)-MgFeO systems, the presence of Fe favors the formation of the the oxygen vacancies resulting in a better activity at lower Cu content. However, it is noteworthy that the acid-base properties of the two series of catalysts are quite different, which may also play a role in this process. 3.4 The stability of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst Given that we managed to prepare a highly active and selective catalyst for the HDO reaction of benzyl alcohol, we also set out to test its stability after multiple catalytic runs. Therefore, first, in order to gather enough spent catalyst for a second run, several reactions using freshly calcined Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst were performed, collecting the spent catalyst after each run. These samples were mixed together, dried at 80 ⁰C overnight, then finely ground and recalcined at 500 ⁰C for 5 h. The catalyst was subjected to another catalytic reaction, retrieved and the procedure described above was repeated one more time. The results obtained in three consecutive reaction runs are presented in Table 7. It can be observed that both the conversion of benzyl alcohol and the selectivity towards toluene diminish after each reaction cycle. This could be attributed to a loss of active sites during the process, mainly Cu2+ and Fe3+ cations, which were shown above to be essential for good yields in the HDO reaction. Cu- and Fe-based catalysts are notoriously easy to degrade in acidic conditions [69–71], and the Cu(10)-MgFeO does not seem to make exception. As noticed above, benzoic acid is clearly detectable in the reaction medium when using benzaldehyde or benzyl benzoate as substrates, and could be the main culprit responsible for this lack of stability. Furthermore, with each run, less and less benzaldehyde was transformed into toluene, a transition directly catalyzed by the Cu and Fe sites, which suggests that this evident deactivation is caused by a loss of active sites either through leaching and/or through decrease of site dispersion. In order to gain a better understanding of the changes the catalytic material underwent during these reaction-recycling steps, the X-ray diffractograms of the fresh catalyst, the spent, unoxidized one, as well as the recalcined, twice-used catalyst were compared in Fig. 3. A portion of the spent catalyst (after the first reaction run) was collected and immediately dried into a flow of helium at 200 ⁰C for 4 h. Afterwards, it was immediately analyzed by means of X-ray diffraction in order to avoid the reoxidation of the solid surface. The diffractograms indicate a noticeable alteration of the mixed oxide’s structure after being used and recalcined, as indicated by the additional reflections that could be ascribed to either a segregated Cu2O (for the used, dried sample) or a separated CuO phase (for the recalcined one). This segregation phenomenon could have impacted the catalyst performance especially in terms of selectivity (as the cupric oxide on its own has proven to be really active), the continuous loss of well-dispersed Cu active sites seemingly having led to a decrease in performance. This effect could be attributed to the dispersion loss caused by the segregated oxides on the catalyst surface. To gain some more insight into the deactivation of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst in these conditions, some qualitative analytical tests were done to see if leaching could also be responsible for the noticed decrease in the catalyst performance. Notably, the mixture of the reaction products usually displayed colours ranging from brown to pale green-blue hues, depending on the used substrate and/or the process conditions. Specifically, the use of benzaldehyde or benzyl benzoate as substrates led to mixtures exhibiting a strong reddish-brown colour, which strongly suggests that the prolonged presence of benzoic acid in the reaction medium leads to Fe3+ leaching as benzoate, if not to Cu2+ as well. This observation is consistent with studies reporting the instability of Fe-based catalysts in the presence of oxalic acid [70] or at low pH generated by various organic acids forming in the medium [72]. Copper leaching has been reported for CuCrO2∙CuO, CuFe2O4∙CuO and CuMn2O4∙CuO catalysts [33], while Mg2+ ions can also be leached out of the catalyst under acidic conditions [69,73]. The leaching of Fe3+ and Cu2+ ions was checked in the reaction products by using specific tests with potassium ferrocyanide for Fe3+ identification and potassium mercury thiocyanate for Cu2+ detection. These tests yielded visible results, suggesting that a detectable quantity of these ions is present in the reaction product mixture: Prussian Blue crystals were observed under the microscope (Fig. S3a), indicating a positive reaction for the ferric ion, and Cu[Hg(SCN)4] crystals, formed in the presence of Cu2+ ions (Fig. S3b), which unambiguously confirm the leaching of these cations during the catalytic process. To resume, both the dispersion loss caused by the segregated oxides on the catalyst surface and the leaching of metals from the solid catalyst through formation of metal salts during the HDO process are the main causes of the observed activity loss. 4 Conclusions The performance of the M-MgFeO mixed oxides was highly dependent on the nature of the transition metal M, the Ag and Cu-containing solids performing the best in terms of activity and/or selectivity. Among the Cu(x)-MgFeO systems, the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst proved to be both highly active and selective in the HDO reaction of benzyl alcohol. Under optimal reaction conditions, this catalyst led to 93.8% conversion of benzyl alcohol and 93.8% selectivity towards toluene, the desired reaction product. The activity of this material was explained by the facile reduction of its active sites observed during the H2-TPR experiment, while the CO2-TPD analysis proved that it is capable of efficiently mediating the benzyl alcohol transformation on the surface Mn+-O2- acid-base pair Lewis sites. The Cu2+ and Fe3+ sites were found to be crucial for the high deoxygenation activity of this catalyst, as they get reduced and enable the formation of oxygen vacancies under the H2 atmosphere, which in turn leads to the hydrogenolysis of the Csp3-O bond in benzyl alcohol via a reverse Mars-van Krevelen mechanism. Furthermore, benzaldehyde was shown to be the key intermediate in the transformation of benzyl alcohol. The activity of the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst diminished by roughly 10% with each run, while the selectivity towards toluene also decreased after the first reaction run; this unwanted deactivation process was attributed to both leaching of Cu2+ and Fe3+ sites and loss of active site dispersion through segregation of Cu-containing phases. coredata.dc:description: Several M-MgFe-LDH precursors were prepared via co-precipitation and then calcined at 500 °C to yield the corresponding M-MgFeO mixed oxide catalysts, which were tested in the hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of benzyl alcohol. The prepared LDH contained Mg and Fe in a mol ratio of 3:1 and 10 at% M with respect to cations, where M = Ni, Co, Ag and Cu. The Cu-MgFeO mixed oxide gave the best results, therefore we proceeded with the preparation of a Cu(x)-MgFeO series, where x = 2.5–20 at% Cu. The prepared solids were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, temperature-programmed reduction with H2, temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy. We studied the influence of the nature of the transition metal M on the activity and selectivity of the catalysts and, for the Cu-containing samples, the influence of Cu loading, reaction time and reaction temperature on their performance in the HDO reaction of benzyl alcohol. With 93.8% conversion and 93.8% selectivity towards toluene at 230 °C, 3 h reaction time and under a hydrogen pressure of 5 atm, the Cu(10)-MgFeO catalyst proved to have the best performance in the studied reaction. Therefore, its stability and reusability were checked. We also proposed a sequence of reactions for the entire HDO process, based on a reverse Mars-van Krevelen mechanism driven by oxygen vacancies formed on the catalyst surface.
coredata.dc:title: Transition metal-containing MgFe ex-LDH mixed oxides, effective catalysts in the hydrodeoxygenation of benzyl alcohol
